author: djm389
title: What is green and white and has some excellent Minifigures?  This set!
review:
With "The LEGO Batman Movie" on the horizon, there has been no shortage of Batman themed LEGO sets. As a rather large Batman fan, I have been looking forward to new interpretations of classic Batman ideas such as the Bat-mobile and Arkham Asylum.  The biggest surprise for me though has been the range of Batman characters made available in minifigure form.  From the Batman Movie Collectable Minifigures to the various sets, there have been some rather obscure characters made LEGO.

This is what inspired me to buy this set.  In total, it includes five minifigures, which is even more than some of the larger Batman Movie sets such as the Batcave and the Lowrider.  I rarely buy sets based on minifigures alone, but for a set that costs thirty American dollars, I found it hard to pass up.  

Minifigures:

I am happy to report that the five minifigures included here did not disappoint.  

I'll start with the most basic of the five: Batman himself.  I will admit that this is the first Batman Movie set that I have opened and built, so I am unsure if every set has the same Batman figure.  As a person who owns many LEGO Batmen, I will say this is a nice one.  It includes a utility belt, which I find to be a plus, and the detail on the torso is simple, but effective.  The face includes two expressions: a stern Batman and a shocked Batman.  I will say that the eyes are a bit strange on the shocked Batman face since they don't completely align with the cowl.  Still, for play and display, this is a serviceable Batman.

Personally, I am a big fan of the Riddler, but have found most of his minifigure variations lacking (outside of the Classic Frank Gorshin Riddler, which I feel is fantastic).  Most of the older Riddler figures look more like a henchman than a major villain.  I am happy to report though that I find this new Riddler figure to be superb.  The torso print is precisely detailed and features many question marks and great printing on the arms (note: all the old figure I have seen just have one question mark).  The hairpiece includes both hair and a proper riddler hat, which I appreciate.  The face features two expressions: smug delight and annoyance, which are the quintessential Riddler expressions in my opinion.  On top of this, the figure holds the classic Riddler cane which includes a well molded green question mark piece.  Overall, I find this to be a stand out figure.

Now, we came to the other three minifigures who are of more obscure villains.  I will admit, there are some villains in the Batman Movie line that I don't recognize, but these three are among some of my more favorite of Batman's lesser known adversaries.

First, there is Kite-man.  His villain name tells it all; he is a man who flies around on a giant kite.  I will say that LEGO perfectly captures this ridiculous character.  He has a rather garish costume featuring a lime green torso with a bright yellow kit emblem, a bright yellow helmet, and a red visor.  On top of this, the figure includes a brick built red and grey kite apparatus.  He has a angry expression, but my favorite part of the figure has to be the extremely happy expression.  Not only does it look great on the figure, but it perfectly encapsulates the Kite-man character.  If you know anything of his comic and cartoon appearances, Kite-man is very happy to be Kite-man.  That is very much on display in this figure.

Next is the minifigure of Magpie, a villain obsessed with shiny things.  To be honest, I have never read a Batman comic that featured Magpie, but she was a large part of the short lived "Beware the Batman" Cartoon Network show.  As the one human being who loved that program, I am glad they seemingly based the minifigure on her appearances from that show.  Magpie has a distinctive white bob as well as a well-detailed face that consists of sharp grey eye liner and crimson markings on both expressions.  The torso piece has some very nice detailing, though it is covered by an upper piece that features a red jewel like centerpiece.  A disappointing aspect of the figure is a lack of legs, instead having a sloped block skirt piece.  Still, despite not being poseable, the block piece has some good detailing on the front.

Last, but not least, we have Calendar Man.  Some people may know the newer version of the character who appears in the Long Halloween graphic novel and the Arkham City video game, who is a rather dark villain and not seemingly fit for LEGO.  This minifigure though is based on the classic silver age version of the character who is far more outlandish.  This is the only one of the five minifigures that has printing on the legs and it very much brings a welcomed pop to the character's design.  His torso includes a makeshift calendar belt that is nicely detailed.  Calendar Man has only one expression, in which he looks very confused.  On his head is a red helmet that features a distinctive grid calendar.  The detail bringing the whole character together has to be the cape.  It comes in two pieces and is frayed in four parts in order to look like the classic calendar cape.

Overall, I think this set is worth it just for the minifigures.  They are great versions of rare characters.  On top of that, they are unique looking and very colorful, so I am sure a child would love them, even if he or she had no idea who the characters were.

The Model:

So, I have spent a lot of time praising the minifigures, but what of the model itself?  Actually, I found myself liking the model aspect of this set far more than I thought I would.  Yes, it's a LEGO car, but I would call it a particularly good LEGO car.  It very much fits the Riddler and includes some nice details.  The back of the car is very interesting and has a unique amount of detail under a clear case piece.  By pressing lightly on it, the back raises up to reveal two missile shooters, which are the set's primary play features.  The colors of the rest of the model include two different shades of green as well as white, which makes it look like some kind of cartoony villainous sports car.  I could see a child being a huge fan of the completed model.

It did not take very long to build and didn't feature any innovative building techniques.  Still, I had a fun time building it for what it was and found it more interesting to build than the average LEGO car.  The sloping front and back were fun to construct and I really liked constructing the back part of the model.

I also think this is an excellent parts pack.  It includes a lot of sloped and triangular pieces in a unique shade of green.  The headlight section could also make for interesting windows.  I could definitely see myself taking the model apart and making some kind of fun MOC out of it.  I could picture the pieces being used for something plant like.

OVERALL:

I am a huge fan of this set and highly recommend it.  It seems to be cheaper in American dollars than in other currencies, but I would consider it a must own for a Batman fan who wants some lesser known Batman figures and a very well designed Riddler figure.  I would also recommend this to parents who want to buy their children a fun LEGO set.  The colors and design of the car and the characters would have really appealed to me as a child.  

I am glad I made this my first LEGO Batman movie set and look forward to building more!

author: ErwinTubeXD
title: Good set!
review: I really love this set!! The Car itself is really a good build and you'll enjoy having this! I suggest buying this if you are a Mini figure collector because this has five good and exotic minifigs!!!! Overall the car and mini figs are incredible and is worth the $30.00 USD!!!

author: Odeinoichus
title: Riddle me this, Riddle me that, whose teaming up against the Big Black Bat?
review:
Set #70903 The Riddler Riddle Racer: This is an awesome set, with five Minifigures and a lot of fun design elements in the model this set is definitely an improvement over the 25$ price point in Canada. I’m not sure why the smaller sets are so ill-conceived, mostly due to the lack of parts in my opinion, but it’s nice to see the higher price points actually doing better than the economy sets.

Box/Instructions

Box: Not as compact as the boxes in the smaller sets, but this one really stands out on the shelf. It draws attention to all the fun characters included in the set and the vehicle, the back is well designed also including some decent action shots for the play features and showing off the alternate faces on the Minifigures.

Instructions: Another single booklet with instructions designed to follow a modular build strategy. There’s very little to say about manuals, easy to use, easy to understand, that’s what LEGO excels on and they’ve improved considerably as time goes on. I do admit though I’m surprised this Theme doesn’t include Minifigure checklists in the back, then again I don’t believe The LEGO Movie had those either, so it is understandable they would be absent for this Theme.

Parts

There’s some green elements here for obvious reasons, The Riddler always decks his stuff in green, you’ll find a nice question mark topper and some nice sloped elements, there’s also a darker green colour in use for some of the elements which are usually used in rooves. A black gold bar piece is also in the set.

Minifigures

Batman: What’s to say about him that hasn’t been said already? He’s basically in every set, the only unique thing about this one is the facial expressions, he has grim face and open mouth scoffing face, it’s all like, I didn’t say that, but he did, you know he did.

Calendar Man: The one decent thing this new film did was give us more and more obscure Batman Rogue’s Gallery members in physical LEGO form. Calendar Man has an awesome looking Calendar shaped cape piece, with matching collar, a very fun and bright looking colour scheme with dual-molded legs, a dual-sided torso print including his number belt, a funky printed head piece with a calendar on the top and a supremely bored looking expression on his face. Calendar Man rocks, no accessories though.

Kite Man: What does this guy do? Rob high-rises only to get gobbled by the Kite-Eating-Tree? What an obscure villain, and all-around some great fun again. Seriously these minfigures are the centerpiece of this Theme. Kite Man features a dual-sided torso print with limited detailing, a yellow helmet covering up his second facial expression, he’s angry and happy, and the best accessory of all.

Kite Man includes a buildable ‘kite’ which attaches to a back-mounted bracket, it’s very intricately detailed with moveable side-wings, some thrusters on the back for extra powered flight and a piece I haven’t seen since Prince of Persia, the one used as a guide for the Camel. Overall a great accessory for another quirky goon.

Magpie: Another obscure villain, a female this time. With a sloped brick for her legs this villain will dynamite Batman to death, she includes two dynamite pieces. She has two expressions, regular smile and angry glower, some excellent torso printing for her outfit and a shoulder piece that… while not exactly Chima related would fit right in with the numerous armour pieces we’ve seen in that Theme. She also has a straight white hair piece first seen in use during The LEGO Movie. First time in this colour if I’m not mistaken.

The Riddler: This version is very reminiscent of Jim Carrey’s portrayal, in the fact that he’s carrying a large question mark topped cane, wearing a bowler hat and a green suit with question marks everywhere including on the sleeves. He’s pretty impressive and I think my favorite interpretation of the character to date, the new head piece with bowler hat and lanky orangeish hair sticking out is a great new piece and I’m looking forward to seeing it in use in other Themes like City.

The build

Bag 1: Batman, Calendar Man and Kite Man are present in this first bag, after building the Minifigures you get to start on the chassis/framework of the Riddle Racer, which features stickers for some detailing. This section of the build wasn’t terribly difficult and much more satisfying than the cheaper sets in the price range.

Bag 2: Magpie and The Riddler join the Minifigures and the rest of the vehicle including the hidden launcher and the headlights. There’s a lot of repetition in this portion of the build, which is to be expected. The engine build is pretty fun too, there’s a lot of personality in this vehicle.

The completed model

Riddle Racer: Aside from Minifigures this model is the big draw for this set, it’s a vehicle for the Riddler to drive around in and it looks great. The mixture of green and white parts really makes this car pop, and the missile launcher is hidden away quite nicely so AFOLs don’t have to see ungainly looking additions to the vehicle build.

It’s very low to the ground too. Just an overall great looking model, the only play feature is a flip up rear engine section to reveal two pressure based missile launchers, but that’s a good thing, you don’t really need loads of features on a car.

Overall opinion

I strongly recommend this set, it’s got four awesome villain figures and a great looking vehicle build, the low curves and the way it hugs the road really makes it look like a race car, something that could look great with the LEGO Speed Racer sets if you happen to have them. Only stickers for details though, no printed elements, just a single sticker with a question mark to put on the hood. Again strongly recommended and much better value compared to the 25$ Mr. Freeze set.

author: DutchFlyer
title: Riddle me this: why did I not get this one earlier?
review:
Summary

This set is in many ways a pleasant surprise to me, and - in hindsight - I wonder why I have not gotten this set earlier. The three bad guys and one bad woman minifigures are excellent, and the car looks quite sleek and nice. The missile launchers are nicely integrated into the build. IMHO the set is fairly expensive - as are most Batman Movie sets - but it still holds up well against its competitor at this price point (the Penguin Arctic Roller) and even slightly higher (the Joker Notorious Low Rider). IMHO The big plus of this set is the number and quality of unique minifigs included. Especially if you see this set at a discount, I would not hesitate to pick it up.

Building experience

There are two builds in this set: the kite for Kite Man is a very small build, and the bigger sports car owned and operated by the Riddler. There are only two stickers that IMHO are essential (dashboard dials and the Riddler sign) to put on. The build itself is quick and easy, the most challenging part for me was making sure I combined the right wing-elements for Kite Man's kite. 

The kit itself can easily be built in 20 minutes, and should not offer any serious issues for children on the lower end of the age range (7-14) given for this set. I did not find the build significantly more challenging than for instance the City Pizza Van (which is given for ages 5-12). The building steps themselves are logical, in small steps and easy to follow in the manual.To me the most interesting aspect of the build was how the designer used many pieces to maximum effect while keeping the build simple and the number of parts down.

Minifigures

The minifigures are one of the strongest aspects, if not the strongest aspect of this set, as most of them are unique and IMHO quite appealing.

Batman is the most uninteresting one, and also the most common of the four Batman-with-utility-belt minifigs around, as it is currently included in 6 sets in the Batman Movie line-up. Kite Man is the only minifigure without an alternate face print.

All four criminals included in this set - Kite Man, Calendar Man, Magpie and the Riddler - are exclusives for this set (though the Riddler in prison garb is included in the Arkham Asylum set). Kite Man, to me, is the most uninteresting figure - by far. The kite is what makes him interesting. 

Calendar Man stands out due to his bright red uniform and his striking cape with Dracula-style collar. The latter has to be folded somewhat to shape it properly though, and is a separate piece.

Magpie in her looks and style - the striking black dress, face and hair - made me first think of a female Dracula, and even somewhat of Darth Malgus. She is armed with some dynamite.

The star figure of this set is the Riddler. As another reviewer has already stated, the minifigure seems inspired by the Jim Carey rendition of this famous villain. If there is anything to nit-pick about with this minifig is that the print of the question marks only covers the back and front of his torso, and not the sides (it does cover the arms though).

The build

Kite Man's kits is nice and small, and a fun little build. It is nice to see what the designer has been able to achieve with a limited number of pieces. The use of pulleys as mirrors is a nice touch.

The Riddler's race car is sleek, and looks fairly small. However, looks are deceiving, as apparently this racer is 'only' 8 cm shorter than the Joker Notorious Low Rider (70906) and only 4 cm shorter than Penguin's Arctic Roller (70911), while being of similar width. The result is very satisfying, and also looks like a car fitting the Riddler's personality - as depicted by Jim Carey. A mini figure easily fits inside behind the steering wheel.

The designer has nicely and effectively modeled the headlights as well as the engine. The engine compartment also hides the spring-loaded missile shooters, and has to be tilted upward to be able to use the missiles. It is only then that the missiles clear the car and the minifig in the driver's seat. Hidden by the central front cover - between the head-lights - is a double barreled cannon.

I like the colour-scheme for the car's exterior and interior, and generally the effort made to cover most studs with smooth tiles. If there is one thing to nit-pick about it is that there is no place to store the Riddler's staff. 

Play vs Display

This set is - it seems - above all intended as a play set. IMHO the car by itself does not stand up well as a pure display model, and the minifigures themselves invite play. The car handles nicely (though perhaps a bit on the large side for the hands of small children), and the missile shooters are integrated well - one is unlikely to launch the missiles by accident, yet they are not difficult to launch when one wants to, and quite easily reloaded.

IMHO the car can be used effectively as a display model when part of a larger display - with other Batman Movie vehicles like the aforementioned Arctic Roller or Notorious Low Rider, or even some of the larger Lego City vehicles - or overall display scheme.

The verdict

Although in price-per-part ratio this kit is expensive (even for the Batman Movie line), I have come to like it more and more. Part of the expense is made up for by the inclusion of 5 minifigures, 4 of them unique to this set. Personally I think Calendar Man, Magpie and especially the Riddler are among the better if not the best minifigures the Batman Movie line has to offer. Riddler's car itself looks good as well. Overall I think this set can seriously compete with the similarly priced Penguin's Arctic Roller and the higher priced Notorious Low Rider. Whether it does so successfully is to some extent a matter or personal taste and preference: do you like the colour-scheme and looks of the vehicle, and are you willing to trade in size of the vehicle for more (and better?) minifigures. IMHO there is nothing wrong with paying regular retail price for this set, and one should seriously consider picking this set up when it is found at a discount.
